help_data.value: The face of the block is finely pecked with a punch. This is typical on finely worked ashlar blocks. Note the plain banding around the perimeter.
The face of the block is punched with diagonal furrows to form a decorative finish.
The face of the block is dressed with a claw to create parallel grooves. The fine claw produced the toolmarks on the left and the coarse claw the toolmarks on the right.
The face of the block is roughly punched as a stage in the facing process. Unfinished blocks could display this characteristic.
The face of the block is punched with opposing diagonal furrows to form the diamond broached pattern.
The face of a soft block of stone is dressed with the heavy use of an axe on the left and with the fine use of an axe on the right.
The punch is used to create furrows as part of the roughing out process.
The face of the block is punched with opposing curved furrows. This is found at Chesters bridge abutment.
The use of an adze with the mason standing over the stone produces these distinctive scoop marks.
Click here to add another example of this type of element. If you want to add a different element then you should close this form and select a new element from the core data table.
This allows you to scroll backwards through the stone recording records.
The allows you to scroll forwards through the stone recording records.
